perturbation.original_text:
1.0 Definitions

a.    "Acceptable Use Policy" means the Acceptable Use Policy for IBM e-business       Services, located on the Internet at http://www.ibm.com/services/       e-business/aup.html, as of the Effective Date, and any subsequent       modification in accordance with Section 13.2 below.
perturbation.changed_text:
1.0 Definitions

a.    "Acceptable Use Policy" means the policy governing use of IBM e-business       Services as defined by IBM. Specific details can be furnished upon request.
perturbation.explanation: The original text explicitly defines the Acceptable Use Policy and links it to a specific URL and future modifications detailed in Section 13.2. The modified text makes the definition vague, stating that IBM defines it and details are 'furnished upon request.' This creates an inconsistency if Section 13.2 is still referenced elsewhere in the contract concerning modifications to the 'Acceptable Use Policy' without a clearly defined initial policy. How are changes made to a policy that is not clearly defined? This change introduces ambiguity in enforcement.

perturbation.original_text:
3.4   Termination for Convenience

Customer may terminate this Agreement (including all Service Option Attachments) or any Service Option Attachment (with the exception of any Service Option Attachment that is a prerequisite for the provision of Services under a non-terminated Service Option Attachment) for convenience at the end of any calendar month by:

a.    providing at least one month's prior written notice to IBM; and

b.    paying the applicable early termination charges, if any, specified in       Attachment A and applicable Service Option Attachments.
perturbation.changed_text:
3.4   Termination for Convenience

Customer may terminate this Agreement (including all Service Option Attachments) or any Service Option Attachment for convenience at the end of any calendar month by:

a.    providing at least one month's prior written notice to IBM; and

b.    paying termination charges.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the phrase 'if any, specified in Attachment A and applicable Service Option Attachments', the text implies that termination charges *always* apply when terminating for convenience. If Attachment A and the Service Option Attachments are silent on termination charges, or state 'no termination charges apply', this creates a direct contradiction. This creates a potential conflict because a 'termination charge' is referenced, but not defined. This ambiguity can lead to disputes over whether charges exist or not.

perturbation.changed_text:
5.3   Security

a.    Customer acknowledges that IBM does not control the transfer of data over       telecommunications facilities, including the Internet.

b.    Subject to the other disclaimers contained herein, IBM will implement security measures. However, IBM does not warrant secure operation of the Services or that it will be able to prevent third party disruptions of the       e-business Hosting Environment or Customer Components.

c.    Customer acknowledges that IBM offers security options. Customer is responsible for selecting on Order Forms the set of security options that it determines meet Customer's needs.

d.    Customer agrees that IBM shall have no liability for any provision of       security-related services or advice that IBM may voluntarily provide       outside the scope of selected Service Option Attachments.
perturbation.explanation: The removal of 'specified herein, including the IBM perform security obligations identified in Section 8.0 of the Facilities Services Service Option Attachment' from 5.3(b) removes the reference to specific security obligations and links to Section 8.0, but this section still states IBM will implement 'security measures'. Similarly, removing 'numerous' and 'specified in Service Option Attachments' makes the offered security options and any means to configure said options for customer needs vague. If other sections reference Section 8.0 for security protocols or rely on service options attachments to enable or modify the provided security features, those references now contradict the current content in Section 5.3(b). This creates uncertainty regarding the contract's security requirements and enforcement.
